attributes.comment:
Thank you for this opportunity to provide input regarding a National Directory of Healthcare Providers & Services on behalf of The Association for Frontotemporal Degeneration (AFTD). AFTD is the only non-profit organization solely dedicated to improving the quality of life of people affected by frontotemporal degeneration (FTD) and driving research to a cure for all FTD disorders, including behavioral variant FTD, primary progressive aphasia and overlapping FTD and ALS.
While FTD is the most common form of dementia in people under 60 it is still rarer than other neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer’s. The most current estimate of prevalence for FTD is around 60,000 cases in the United States. As is the case with other rare diseases, people diagnosed and their family and caregivers struggle to find professional help with diagnosis, care and support from providers with experience in FTD disorders. To serve people with FTD and their families and care-partners the National Directory of Healthcare Providers & Services must do the following.

•Include a mechanism for providers to indicate their level of experience and knowledge with rare diseases such as FTD.
•Enable providers to locate other specialists with experience in FTD or other rare diseases across the full range of healthcare services from diagnosis to end-of-life care.
•Allow access for rare disease advocacy organizations to submit information on support groups and other informal networks for information about specialized providers
•Include information about care planning and management services for rare diseases
•Include information about financial and legal planning and employment law for people with rare disease who are unable to work but under the age of retirement

A National Directory of Healthcare Providers & Services could be a great resource for people living with and caring for a loved one with a rare disease like FTD if it contains current and accurate information about the specialized services people so desperately need.
